rev.diff:
Line 138: Line 138:
On 14 January 2011, protests took place in Jordan's capital Amman, Maan, Karak, Salt and Irbid and other cities. The protests, led by trade unionists and [[leftist]] parties, came after [[Friday prayers]], and called for the government led by Prime Minister [[Samir Rifai]] to step down. They chanted anti-government slogans and called Rifai a "coward." One banner in the protest read "Jordan is not only for the rich. Bread is a red line. Beware of our starvation and fury," while protesters chanted "Down with Rifai's government. Unify yourselves because the government wants to eat your flesh. Raise fuel prices to fill your pocket with millions." Tawfiq al-Batoush, a former head of the Karak municipality, said: "We are protesting the policies of the government, high prices and repeated taxation that made the Jordanian people revolt."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111141219337111.html |title=Jordanians march against inflation â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref> The [[Muslim Brotherhood#Jordan|Muslim Brotherhood]] and 14 trade unions said they would hold a sit-down protest outside parliament the next day to "denounce government['s] economic policies." Parallels were drawn with the Tunisian protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/15/jordanians-protest-over-food-prices|title=Jordanians protest against soaring food prices|author=Johnny McDevitt}}</ref>
On 14 January 2011, protests took place in Jordan's capital Amman, Maan, Karak, Salt and Irbid and other cities. The protests, led by trade unionists and [[leftist]] parties, came after [[Friday prayers]], and called for the government led by Prime Minister [[Samir Rifai]] to step down. They chanted anti-government slogans and called Rifai a "coward." One banner in the protest read "Jordan is not only for the rich. Bread is a red line. Beware of our starvation and fury," while protesters chanted "Down with Rifai's government. Unify yourselves because the government wants to eat your flesh. Raise fuel prices to fill your pocket with millions." Tawfiq al-Batoush, a former head of the Karak municipality, said: "We are protesting the policies of the government, high prices and repeated taxation that made the Jordanian people revolt."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111141219337111.html |title=Jordanians march against inflation â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref> The [[Muslim Brotherhood#Jordan|Muslim Brotherhood]] and 14 trade unions said they would hold a sit-down protest outside parliament the next day to "denounce government['s] economic policies." Parallels were drawn with the Tunisian protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/15/jordanians-protest-over-food-prices|title=Jordanians protest against soaring food prices|author=Johnny McDevitt}}</ref>
â
On 16 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread â Bloomberg<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Protests in Egypt also led to a man setting himself on fire. Many Egyptians also set up ''Facebook'' pages calling for January 25 to be "a day of revolution against torture, poverty, corruption and unemployment."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12204999|title=Man sets himself on fire in Cairo protest}}</ref>
+
On 16 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread â Bloomberg<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Protests in Egypt also led to [[Abdou Abdel-Moneim Jaafar|a man setting himself on fire]]. Many Egyptians also set up ''Facebook'' pages calling for January 25 to be "a day of revolution against torture, poverty, corruption and unemployment."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12204999|title=Man sets himself on fire in Cairo protest}}</ref>
